body_html:
@vclteam, the issue here was resolved without tweaking the code.

At the beginning of freeze.py file it is mentioned that the flags used during training command have to be preserved during the freezing too: "One thing to watch out for is that you need to pass in the same arguments for sample_rate and other command line variables here as you did for the training
script." So in my case I had to use the flag --wanted_words=yes again here ,something that I hadn't done previously.

In your case(#13581), I think if you have trained with the --clip_duration_ms=1000, then you can't change it to 2800 at the freezing stage. May I know if this is the case?
body_text:
@vclteam, the issue here was resolved without tweaking the code.
At the beginning of freeze.py file it is mentioned that the flags used during training command have to be preserved during the freezing too: "One thing to watch out for is that you need to pass in the same arguments for sample_rate and other command line variables here as you did for the training
script." So in my case I had to use the flag --wanted_words=yes  again here ,something that I hadn't done previously.
In your case(#13581), I think if you have trained with the --clip_duration_ms=1000, then you can't change it to 2800 at the freezing stage. May I know if this is the case?
body:
@vclteam, the issue here was resolved without tweaking the code.

 At the beginning of freeze.py file it is mentioned that the flags used during training command have to be preserved during the freezing too: "One thing to watch out for is that you need to pass in the same arguments for `sample_rate` and other command line variables here as you did for the training
script." So in my case I had to use the flag --wanted_words=yes  again here ,something that I hadn't done previously.

In your case(https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/13581), I think if you have trained with the --clip_duration_ms=1000, then you can't change it to 2800 at the freezing stage. May I know if this is the case?
